snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay: In the video, he said the growth rate was 15 percent at the time her recorded the video on March 6. As of today, one week later, if you calculate the growth rate  you get X^7• 21,000= 139,000. If you solve for x, x=1.30 which is a 30 percent increase in the number of cases daily. That means, dispute our efforts to quarantine and self isolation, we are no where near the inflection point and are actually spreading the virus at a higher rate than a week ago.
snippet.textOriginal: In the video, he said the growth rate was 15 percent at the time her recorded the video on March 6. As of today, one week later, if you calculate the growth rate  you get X^7• 21,000= 139,000. If you solve for x, x=1.30 which is a 30 percent increase in the number of cases daily. That means, dispute our efforts to quarantine and self isolation, we are no where near the inflection point and are actually spreading the virus at a higher rate than a week ago.

snippet.textDisplay:
I learnt more about Coronavirus from this maths video than I have from health experts.

I work in Psychology, and it's interesting how the maths here is completely intuitive for me working with stats, and I've been trying to say to people for a while now that the new cases per day are not a good measure of how well or poorly a country is doing.
snippet.textOriginal:
I learnt more about Coronavirus from this maths video than I have from health experts. 

I work in Psychology, and it's interesting how the maths here is completely intuitive for me working with stats, and I've been trying to say to people for a while now that the new cases per day are not a good measure of how well or poorly a country is doing.

Based on today's number of 53,955, it would seem the average ratio has been 1.14 since 3/6 (21,395 per this video):

21,395*(1.14)^7 = 53,536 (very close to actual amount)

I don't believe we're at the inflection point yet. :(

snippet.textDisplay:
Hello.
Good video and puts things into some sort of logical perspective.
suggestion:
Can you update this weekly to try and determine when we are at or approaching the inflection point ?

It would be an interesting experiment to see we can predict the turnaround using this model.
It would also help people to calm down if we can predict that we are near the turnaround point.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hello.
Good video and puts things into some sort of logical perspective.
suggestion:
Can you update this weekly to try and determine when we are at or approaching the inflection point ?

It would also help people to calm down if we can predict that we are near the turnaround point.

snippet.textDisplay:
Maybe it's just to do with being over 35, but I really have a hard time with how the young have decided to suddenly change the way they pronounce the letter 'u'.

There are four ways to say it, as in these words: use, dune, pull, and sun. Each of course has its place. But millennials have started messing with the distinctions, for some odd reason. 'Mulitply' and 'result' are the most common cases. Suddenly they say the 'u' sound in these words not as in 'sun' but as in 'pull'.

How odd it is for people to learn a word and then one day say "I really must now start saying this word differently. I believe I'll find that satisfying." I find it mindless, loathsome trendiness probably amounting to identity-building and herd-following for those in search of an identity and a herd.
snippet.textOriginal:
Maybe it's just to do with being over 35, but I really have a hard time with how the young have decided to suddenly change the way they pronounce the letter 'u'.

There are four ways to say it, as in these words:  use, dune, pull, and sun.  Each of course has its place.  But millennials have started messing with the distinctions, for some odd reason.  'Mulitply' and 'result' are the most common cases.  Suddenly they say the 'u' sound in these words not as in 'sun' but as in 'pull'.

How odd it is for people to learn a word and then one day say "I really must now start saying this word differently.  I believe I'll find that satisfying."  I find it mindless, loathsome trendiness probably amounting to identity-building and herd-following for those in search of an identity and a herd.

snippet.textDisplay: It was nice explanation of exponential growth model . However it is not model of corona virus fortunately. I believe so,because since outbreak of the corona virus in China in December 2019 there were ca 82 000 of people infected until March 11( in over 3 months) ,which is 0.0057 % of whole China population. Today' China submitted announcement that number of new infections decreased.In the world growth of infection is also related to the way it is handled in different countries (one can compare rapid or exponential growth in Italy with rather slower rate of growth in Germany and France ) which means there are many other factors that can affect the algorithm of corona virus spreading around the world. I am not an expert I'm just guessing.
snippet.textOriginal: It was nice explanation of exponential growth model . However it is not  model of  corona virus fortunately. I believe so,because since outbreak of the corona virus in China in December 2019  there were ca 82 000 of people infected until March 11( in over 3 months)  ,which is 0.0057 % of whole China population. Today'   China submitted announcement that number of new infections decreased.In the world growth of infection is also related to the way it is handled in different countries (one can  compare rapid or exponential growth in Italy with rather slower rate of growth in Germany and France ) which means there are many other factors that can affect the algorithm of corona virus  spreading around the world. I am not an expert I'm just guessing.
